user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_WaitForStateChange_Impl:
```c
void OS_WaitForStateChange_Impl(osal_objtype_t idtype, uint32 attempts)
{
    OS_impl_objtype_lock_t *impl;
    struct timespec         ts;

    impl = OS_impl_objtype_lock_table[idtype];

    /*
     * because pthread_cond_timedwait() is also a cancellation point,
     * this pushes a cleanup handler to ensure that if canceled during this call,
     * the mutex will be released.
     */
    pthread_cleanup_push(OS_Posix_ReleaseTableMutex, &impl->mutex);

    clock_gettime(CLOCK_REALTIME, &ts);

    if (attempts <= 10)
    {
        /* Wait an increasing amount of time, starting at 10ms */
        ts.tv_nsec += attempts * attempts * 10000000;
        if (ts.tv_nsec >= 1000000000)
        {
            ts.tv_nsec -= 1000000000;
            ++ts.tv_sec;
        }
    }
    else
    {
        /* wait 1 second (max for polling) */
        ++ts.tv_sec;
    }

    pthread_cond_timedwait(&impl->cond, &impl->mutex, &ts);

    pthread_cleanup_pop(false);
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
pthread_cleanup_push(OS_Posix_ReleaseTableMutex, &impl->mutex);
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 8.13 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: The pointer passed (&impl->mutex) is intended for use with pthread_cleanup_push and the cleanup routine that will release/unlock the mutex. The cleanup API takes a void* (non-const) and the mutex is a mutable object that will be modified by the cleanup handler, so it cannot reasonably be const-qualified. Therefore this use does not violate MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13.
